subject: Re: [junit] Re: Categories in JUnit4?

messageBody:
Jon Skeet wrote:
> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@r...> wrote:
> > > So, why am I wrong? :)
> >
> > You're not wrong, but I do something differently, and prefer it.
>
> Does that mean you've tried the annotation way of working for a
> significant amount of time?

Yes, although I did it with tag interfaces, rather than with
annotations. I then had test case filters that collects all tests that
implemented a given interface, like DatabaseTest, AcceptanceTest,
PerformanceTest, and so on. After about 3 months, I noticed that I
wasn't running the "Database" tests, and that only a handful of test
case classes implemented more than one interface. I also noticed that I
was running all the tests most of the time, anyway.
>
> > Tests sometimes naturally divide themselves along the axis of "how
> > often we run them".
>
> That's certainly *one* aspect of how they divide themselves. However,
> there's more than that.
>
> <snip>
>
> I separate production source from test source, but currently all our
> test cases are in one tree (per project).
>
> The main problem I see with your solution (other than it not keeping
> all the tests for one class in a single easily findable place) is that
> it only works while you've only got one axis you want to divide the
> tests up by. Another axis which is relevant for us is which area of
> functionality is involved - and that may not always be feasible on a
> package/namespace basis. For instance, if all db-schema-sensitive
> tests are categorised as such, then after making a schema change I can
> run all those tests, whether they're also performance tests or not.

Why can't you run all the /unit/ tests before a check-in? Don't they
mostly all run in memory, anyway?

Also, since database-related tests are usually slower than tests that
run entirely in memory, is there /really/ a big difference in execution
time between running all the database-related tests and running /all/
the tests. In my experience, the difference is usually measured in tens
of seconds, and not tens of minutes. After all, 1000 in-memory tests
usually run in 10-30 seconds. What's 10-30 seconds more, compared to a
test run that takes 20-30 minutes? For that matter, what's 1-2 minutes
more? Why not just run all the tests, rather than spend the extra time
categorizing them just so?

> In
> the situation where running *all* unit tests just isn't feasible
> before every check-in, being easily able to choose which tests are run
> (across both NUnit and JUnit, by the way) to verify that nothing's
> been broken requires more flexibility than a single axis would
> provide.

In a configuration that complex, I would probably not have enough
confidence to ship code without running every single test. If the system
is really that big, and test runs take hours, then I would immediately
evaluate the benefits of splitting that system into loosely coupled
parts and evolving them in separate source trees. My hunch is that the
result would be easier to manage and would have much faster tests, on
the whole.

Do bear in mind how much I'm speculating. It's possible that you've
already considered all this and rejected it; but I've simply never found
myself in such a situation, so I'm imagining how I would deal with that
situation if I found myself in it.
